title: Ukrainian borscht

ingredients.content: 100 g brown onion, cut into quarters
250 - 300 g baby beetroot, peeled, reserving 7 leaves and stalks, cut into pieces (3 cm)
60 g carrot, cut into pieces (3 cm)
50 g celery stalk, cut into pieces (3 cm)
150 g potato, peeled and cut into pieces (3-4 cm)
60 g cabbage, cut into pieces (3 cm)
60 g parsnip, peeled and cut into pieces (3 cm)
400 g canned cannellini beans, rinsed and drained (approx. 250 g after draining)
2 spring onions/shallots, cut into thin slices

preparations.content: Place garlic, onion and beetroot into mixing bowl and chop <b>3 sec/speed 5<b>. Transfer into a bowl and set aside.
Place carrot, celery, potato, cabbage and parsnip into mixing bowl and chop <b>2 sec/speed 5<b>.
Add water, stock paste, pepper, allspice berries, bay leaf, reserved beetroot mixture and reserved beetroot leaves and stalks and cook <b>20 min/90°C//speed 1<b>.

Add cannellini beans, tomato paste and lemon juice and mix <b>1 min 30 sec//speed 1<b>. Divide between serving bowls, top each with 1 tablespoon of sour cream and garnish with sliced spring onions/shallots before serving.

hintsAndTricks: Please refer to The Basic Cookbook or the Everyday Cookbook for the Chicken stock paste recipe.
You can replace the cabbage with sauerkraut, if preferred. To make your own, please refer to the recipe on this recipe chip.
Borscht is typically a thinner soup (similar to a broth) and often served with dumplings in it. Ukranian borscht is much heartier and chunkier, containing a wide variety of vegetables.
